cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Chief Offices–9 & 10, FENCHURCH STREET, LONDON, E.C.
Factory–TOWER HILL (opposite the Tower of London).
And at CAPE TOWN and JOHANNESBURG.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MAIL S.S. CO., LTD.

By the Magnificent British Turbine Steamers S.S. "HELIOPOLIS" & "CAIRO," 12,000 tons gross, 18,000 horse power.
ALEXANDRIA to NAPLES 2 Days; ALEXANDRIA to MARSEILLES, 3 Days; ALEXANDRIA to LONDON, 4 Days
DEPARTURES – 14th, 26th December; and 9th, 23rd, 30th January, and WEEKLY thereafter.

General passenger Agents for Egypt–Reise Bureau of the Hamburg-Amerika Line, Grand Continental Hotel Buildings, Cairo. – For freight and particulars apply E. BARBER & SON, General Agents, Alexandria. London Office – 3, Waterloo Place, Pall Mall, S.W. 31159 – 26-10-908

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.

R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Suez about December 13
R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about December 27.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said aboutDecember 16
R.M.S. "Oreya" will leave Port Said aboutDecember 30

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Suez about December 19th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Port Said about December 9th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Greece-Turkey Mall Service.- Shortest, calment, most beautiful sea package to Europe. Express steamers leave Alexandria 4 p.m. every Wednesday for Piræus. (Athens), Smyrne, Mitylene, Constantinople, in connection with Orient Express luxe train for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, London.

Palestine-Syria Mail Service with Extension to Turkey. - Fast steamers leave Alexandria 4pm every Saturday and Port Srid, 5 p.m., every Sunday for Jaffs, (Jerusalero), Caiffa, (Nazareth) Beyrouth, (Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandrette, Mersins, Larnaca, pontinging in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople

Sudan-Express Mail Services. - KKHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express stenteers leave Svez 5 pm, every Wednesday for Port Sudan (and Suskin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe Service to Khartoum, arriving 8 pm Saturdays.

Red-Sea Coasting Mail Service.- Steamers from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for Jedds, calling one week at Tor, El-Wedj Yambo, Jedda ; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jodca, Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeida, Aden.
For freight or passages apply the Co's Agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo or for passages only toTHOS. COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA Linie RKISK BURREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: SUDAN-RED SEA MAIL SERVICE
div.p: Khedivial Line's Express Mail Steamers leave Suez Docks every Wednesday, 5 p.m., arriving Port Sudan, Fridays, 6 p.m., Suakim, Sundays 3 p.m. Depart Suakim, Tues. noon, depart Port Sudan, Thurs, 10 a.m., arriving Suez Docks, Saturdays 3 p.m.

Departures from Suez after arrival of Brindisi Mail. Through carriages in connection with steamer attached to 11 a.m. train from Cairo. In connection with mail steamer a train (sleeping and dining cars) leaves Port Sudan, 8 p.m. Fridays, arr. Khartoum, Saturday, 8 p.m. From Kartoum, a train (sleeping and dining cars) leaves Tuesday, 9:15 p.m. arriving Port Sudan Wednesday 8 p.m. Passengers may remain night in sleeping cars. On arrival at Suez, through cariages are attached to 5:40 p.m. train to Cairo. 31371--22-11-908A

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from BORDEUAX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for con- veyances of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns. For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria Agent- The following are expected at Alexandria: Dec. 16 S.S. "Pyrgos" from Hamburg,- Dec. 18 S.S. "Hythnos" from Antwerp. S.S. "Angantyr" now in port discharging.

S.S.Philae now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, 14th December, to be followed by S.S. Monepthah.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from ALEXANDRIA to BRINDISI TIRESTE (VENICE), leave Saturdays at 4 p.m. having connection in Brindisi with the Express train on Tuesday morning to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London. Arrival at Trieste on Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leaves the same evening, 6.35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussels, Ostende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5.12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Steamers from Alexandria to Trieste via Brindisi leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m.

div.head: A GOOD START IN LIFE.
div.p: Mothers should early realize how essential good health is for the success of their child in after life. A badly nourished baby generally means an undersized child, wanting in stamina and vigour. If unable to nurse your baby you must give the substitute that most closely resembles human milk. No farinaceous or starchy food or unmodified cow's milk is permissible to a child under 6 or 7 months of age. The "Allensburys" Milk Foods are so prepared as to remove the difference between cow's milk and human milk, and they are as easy of digestion as the natural food of the child.

The "Allenburys" Foods are alike suitable for the delicate and robust, and, when used as directed, form the best means of rearing a child by hand. The No. 1 Milk Food may be given alternately with the mother's milk without fear of upsetting the child or causing digestive disturbance. The dreaded process of weaning is thus made easy and comfortable both to the mother and child.
The 'Allenburys' Foods.
MILK FOOD No. 1
From birth to 3 months
MILK FOOD No. 2
From 3 to 6 months
MALTED FOOD No. 3
From 6 months and upwards.
PAMPHLET ON INFANT FEEDING SENT FREE
ALLEN & HANBURYS Ltd., 37, LOMBARD STREET, LONDON, E.C.

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1907.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: Included in a house party assembled in the Eastern Counties some two-and-twenty years ago was a young man who entered with spirit into all the amusements of a very gay week. There was a county ball in the neighbouring town, besides dancing and amusements of all kinds in the country house itself. Of these gaieties the young man in question was the life and soul. Few of those who formed that house party in the mid-eigbties foresaw the eminence to which their fellow-guest would attain, though many were struck with the brilliance of his conversation and the pungency of bis wit. One or two predicted for him a great future.

These last were in the right for Eldon Gorst has in these twenty-odd years risen to quite a dazzling height in the service of his country. It was just after the house party in question that he first entered the Foreign Office, at the age of twenty-four. He had, it is true, certain preliminary advantages that stood him in good stead. The son of a distinguished father--for even at that time Sir John Gorst was SolicitorGeneral, and in the following year he became under-Secretary for India--Eldon Gorst had been educated at Eton, and had gone thence to Trinity College, Cambridge, whence he emerged twentieth wrangler. Yet these are advantages shared by many who elect to make diplomacy their profession. It was this young man's own personality that 80 soon made its mark, leading bim on through the various grades of attachd, third Secretary and second Secretary, until he became, in the year 1890, a very important personage as Controller of Direct Taxes to the Egyptian Government. Here was an opening that gave scope for the brain-power that Nature had given Mr. Eldon Gorst in no scant measure. In two years he became Under-Secretary of State for Finance, and two years later came to him the post of Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior. These important offices brought their holder, of course, into close relations with Lord Cromer, whose understudy he became and that so successfully that five years ago & grateful Government improved plain Mr. Bldon Gorst into Sir Eldon Gorst by bestowing on him a Civil K.C.B. It is only during the present year, however, that the clever young diplomat of twenty years ago attained to the bigbest reward that comes of long service in Egypt. Lord Cromer, from motives of health and because of advancing years, last spring elected to retire from his responsible position in Cairo. Who so fit to succeed him as Sir Eldon Gorst, trained for so many years under his watcbtul eye ? So the man of the moment was there at the moment, and now, at the age of torty-six, finds himselt the deus ex machina of all the complicated network of Egyptian affairs.

Even bis most ardent admirers will not be disposed to consider Sir Eldon Gorst particularly imposing in his personal appearance. He is quite unusually short, as the men of these days go, with rather a stoop of the shoulders, and short sight necessitates his wearing pince-nez at all times and seasons. Yet bis is an exceedingly clever face, and the eyes, even through their spectacles, have a merry, bright twinkle that shows a keen sense of humonr. In former days no one entered more keenly into the social gaieties of Cairo, and Mr. Gorst, as he then was, in spite of being a man of affairs, managed to be at all the amusing pienio parties, balls, and dinners of the winter season in Egypt. Four years ago, bowever, having waited till he was well over forty, Sir Eldon settled down to matrimony; he wooed and won the daughter of a well-known South African financier, Mr. Charles Rudd, and their wedding in Lancaster Gate was one of the events of the season of 1908. Lady Gorst is a very charming and po pular lady, who will do the honours of the British Consulate General with much of the grace that made her predecessor, Lady Cromer, so well liked during these last five seasons at Cairo. To complete the good fortune of Sir Eldon Gorst-to whom, surely, the gods have been extraordinarily kind-there is a young hopeful, who has just accompanied Lady Gorst to Egypt, and will, no doubt, in time carry on the traditions of a specially talented family to the third generation.-(From "The World" Egypt Supplement.)

div.head: Covernment Offio. Moura.
div.p: The Government office hours during 1908 will be from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

div.head: Cerman Training Ship.
div.p: This morning the German naval training ship. "Freya" entered Alexandria harbour. The usual salutes were given and returned.

div.head: The Thunderbolt at Ramleh.
div.p: The two cooks, of the Hotel Miramare at Fleming, who were burt by the thunderbolt, which struck that hotel last Saturday, are getting better. All the damage done to the hotel has been repaired.

div.head: Army Medionl Inapootlon.
div.p: Col. J. M. Jones, P. M. O. in Egypt, acoompanied by Major Hardy, RAM.C., arrived in Alexandria yesterday and is making his annual medical inspection of the camps and barracks of the Army of Occupation here.

div.head: Coal Importe.
div.p: Between January 1 and December 5, 1,249,603, tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 694,146 tons were Welsh, 152,045 Newcastle, 181,018 Yorkshire, 95,931 Scotch and 136,463 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,199,558.

div.head: Births and Deathe.
div.p: A total of 10 European and 623 native births and 15 European and 337 native deaths are recorded in Cairo for the week ending December 2nd. Infant mortality has increased amongst the natives, no less than 209 out of the total of 337 being of children under the age of five years. The European deaths include five children in the numbers given. Ten deaths were due to diphtheria, two to typhus including one European to typhoid, one to erysipilas, and one to puerperal fever.

div.head: New Egyptian Co.
div.p: A meeting of shareholders of the New Egyptian Company was held on Thursday afternoon at the Cairo headquarters of the International Chamber of Commerce. 23,417 shares were represented. The object of the meeting was to select a committee of shareholders to demand & statement as to the financial position of the Company from its representatives in Cairo and, if necessary, to have recourse to London. Messrs Paul Oziol, Saint Claire Deville and Cohen were chosen.

div.head: Delta Chaplainoy
div.p: The following services will be held during the present month at the English churches of Tantab and Mansourah :- TANTAH. December 8th at 6.30 p.m.; 15th at 8 a.m. and 11 a.m. (Holy Communion at 11.45 a.m. it required); 22nd at 6.30 p.m. Christmas Day, Holy Com inunion at 11 a.m. ; 29th at 8 a.m. and 11 a.m. MANSOURAH. December 8th at 11 a.m.; 15th at 6.30 p.m. ; 22nd at 8 a. m. and 11 a.m. ; Christmas Day Holy Communion at 7.45 a.m. ; 29th at 6.30 p.m.

div.head: Novel Advertising.
div.p: Quite an original form of advertisement display was witnessed last night at the Ter minus of the Ramleh line, where by means of limelight, various advertisements interspersed with excellent views were thrown upon a large screen. The position is excellent, facing agits does the Boulevard de Ramleh, but we would war the Express Publicité, who have adopted this idea, that their enterprise may cause much comment, if not more serious consequences, by the dislocation of traffic through the crowds gathering in the roadway to witness a free show.

div.head: Egypt and Amerloan Cotton.
div.p: The "New York American" remarks :"Many persons believe that cotton will go lower, but some of those who believe this are trying to terrify the Southern planters by pointing to Egypt Egypt has had many chances to raise all the cotton the world needed, but it has never been able to increase its prodaetion materially. Improvements for handling the water of the Nile were made some years ago. They did not result in any increase in the cotton crop, although they did produce an immense crop of scandal in London and Alexandria The United States is secure in its control of the cotton market, but in spite of that cotton seems to be pointing downward simply because a season of economy has settled all over the world.

div.head: Palestine Exploration Fund.
div.p: The quarterly review of the Palestine Explor ation Fund contains much matter of grent interest to archæologists. In this review Mr. Stewart Macalister, M.A., F.S.A., continues his report on the excavation of Gezer and also contribntes an uncompleted translation of a most interesting article on specimens of fellah wit and humour by a certain Yusif Khattar Kina' an. In addition to these Mr. Macalister furnishes a description of a mosaic newly discovered at Jerusalem Other articles of interest include the Immovable Fast by Pbilip J. Baldensperger. The Bedouin of the Sinaitic Peninsula by W.E. Jennings Bramley. Notes on the Geography of Palestine by the Rev. Caleb Hauser, A. The Acra of the Greeks by J.M Tenz. Interesting Coins of Pella and Bittir by Archdeacon Dowling, Haita. An Ancient Gate East of the Holy Sepulchre Dead Sea Observations by Dr. E. W. Gurney Masterman. Meteorological Observations taken at Tiberiais in the years 1904-1906 by Rasheed Nassar.
THE
Hotel Casino San Stefano
Will be open during Winter. REDUCED PRICES

div.head: CONGO FREE STATE
THE TRANSFER TO BELGÍUM.
div.p: The treaty transferring the Congo Free State to Belgium has just been made public and is aronsing considerable interest. It is a somewhat ambiguous political document. The annexes, documents and complementary dispositions of the treaty have been kept serret as yet. The correspondent of the “Daily Telegraph” at Brussels says that the treaty has produced a bad effect in well-informed circles there.

div.head: MACEDONIA. JUDICIAL REFORM.
div.p: According it a statement made in "The Times" to day the Ambassadors of the Powers interested in the Macedonian question are reported to have arrived at a complete harmonions agreement, regarding a scheme for judicial reform in Macedonia. Acoording to this scheme it is stipulated that inspectors be appointed, half of whom are to be Moslems and half Christians. These inspectors will be ordered to report to the Financial Commission It is also stipulated that a European jurist should be nominated to & seat on the Commission as a legal expert

div.head: EGYPT'S DANGER
div.p: Two interesting speeches, representing the different points of view in regard to the policy to be pursued in regard to this country, were made last week. The standpoint of the cosmopolitan European financier is tersely expressed in the statement as to the situation in Egypt made by Baron G. de Reuter, who presided over the second ordinary meeting of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt. The official report of his speech was published in our issue of yesterday, but the remarks which we will now quote were not included therein, althongh considerable prominence is given to them in the London newspapers. The Baron, in moving the adoption of the report, said that during the last twenty-four years the progress of Egypt hac been phenomenal from an economical point of view. The position of the fellah had been immensely improved. He wanted to be left alone to cultivate his ground and to be free from the unjust impositions with which he was burdened in the past. The idea that he wanted Parliamentary repre-entation was not serious, and those persons who were really acquainted with the country scoffed at the notion.

"Lord Cromer, at the Guildhall, last month, adverting to this question, stated, that he viewed the extremists in this country who had misled the Egyptians as to the true trend of feeling here as the worst enemies of Egyptian progress : the extremists, were mischievous because of their suggestion of changes for which the state of Egypt was not yet ripe."

It the edifice, which we have built up here, shonld crumble owing to the policy of the Radical extremists, the Baron pointed out that it was those who had financial interests in this country who would suffer, whether they be foreigners or Egyptians, and he therefore, appealed to the shareholders as business men to do what they could to nip such a danger in the bud. “It was in their power to do it. The extremists in Egypt only existed because they counted upon a certain support in this country and on the Continent; and if that support be denied them they would inevitably and completely cease to exist. All Europeans having a stake in Egypt deplored this fanning of the Aame in England, as they leemed it disastrous to all concerned.”

Elsewhere in yesterday's issue we give publicity to an equally characteristic utterance by the very type of person, whose dangerous theo ries are stignatised by Baron de Reuter. The lecture on Egypt by the Radical "doctrinaire," Mr. Robertson, M.P., is the expression of a dia. metrically opposite point of view, which holds financiers as persons of no account in comparison with the realisation of "a priori" theories as to the melioration of Egypt in accordance with Radical panaceas.

div.head: A CAIRO REVIEW.
div.p: A weekly review is shortly to make its appearance in Cairo. The editor will be Mr. Charles Rudy, the editor of the "Egyptian Standard," who is shortly leaving the service of Mustapha Pasha Kamel for a more con genial occupation of editing a political, social and economic review. It is to be published on or shortly after the beginning of the New Year. The political standpoint of Mr. Rudy's organ will be quite independent. We wish our new contemporary every success and we are sure that its editor will find his new venture far more to his taste than his journalistic association with the Pasha whose treatment of his European employés has aroused aniversal indignation among all pressmen in Egypt.

Cheap Cas from Common Fuels for Engines, Manufacturing, Furnaces, Pump ing, Irrigation, Incandescent Lighting and Generation of Electricity. Lane's Producers are available for Land, River or Ocean Service. Agents required. Address Howard Lane, 125 Edmund Street, Birmingham, England.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL. FRENCH PRESS INDIGNANT.
div.p: The French Press in Cairo of every shade of opinion is unanimous in its condemnation of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's conduct to Mr. Kastner, the late editor of the "Etendard Egyptien." Kamel violated all the principles of professional etiquette and also all the ordinary rules of courtesy by announcing in the "Etendard" that Mr. Kastner had been dismissed, for our French contemporaries declare that this is untrue, as Mr. Kastner sent a letter to Kamel, twenty four hours prior to the alleg. ed distnissal, announcing that he intended severing his connection with Mustapha Pasha Kamel and Company

Our observations on the question would only be interpreted as emanating from a naturally prejudiced source, so we will confine ourselves to quoting the opinion of some Cairo organs, "untainted by Imperialistic prejudice," and we commend the perusal of these comments to Mr. Wilfrid Blunt and the other supporters of Kamel at home.
The Anglophobe "Orient," whose sympathies with Egyptian Nationalism have of late become very pronounced, remarks -

"L'attitude de Moustapha Kamel dans l'incident actuel nous oblige à déclarer que si nous sommes des admirateurs de sa politique, nous ne saurions approuver son attitude comme directeur de journal. L'Etendard" n'admet pas que les contrères "pleurnichent” sur le cas de notre ami Kastner. Il revendique pour le journaliste la liberté S'il vent parler de la liberté de traiter ses collaborateurs, aussi cavalièrement, ce n'est plus de la liberté du journaliste qu'il s'agit. Il faut s'entendre."
The "Bourse Egyptienne" says :
"L'opinion unanime de la presse, comme celle du public, sera du côté de notre ami M Kastner.
The "Journal du Caire" remarks: -

Il nons sera permis de regretter que le départ de M. Kastner ait été annoncé par l'Eter.dard" en termes peu courtois. C'est la facheuse façon d'illustrer, par des faits, la théorie da rapprochement entre Egyptiens et Européens. En toute chose, il y a une manière; celle de l'"Etendard" n'est certainement pas la bonne."

"L'Egypte" devotes a considerable space to criticising the conduct of the Pasha, both as regards the Editor of the "Etendard Egyptien" and also in the case of the Editor of the "Egyptian Standard." We extract the following passage from the leading article in to-day's issue of that newspaper :

Ce qu'il y a de particulièrement grave clans les décisions du pacha, c'est qu'elles sont froidement calculées. Elles ont pour but de creuser davantage si possible le fossé profond qni, grâce aux gens de son espèce, rend tout rapprochement impossible entre Egyptiens et étrangers. Mustapha Kamel ne veut pas tenir compte de l'immense sacrifice moral consenti à son soi-disant patriotisme par ceux qui eurent le courage de le servir. Il engage des journalistes pour l'encenser et les congédie pour se distraire. Il appelle cela la liberté. La liberté ? La liberté de l'injastice sans doute ?

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS. TRIAL OF THE OFFICIALS.
div.p: The successor of Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, as Director General of the Administration of Ports and Lighthouses, will probably arrive in Egypt from England in the course of next month.
The trial of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration, accused of bribery and corruption, will begin on Monday next, the 9th inst, at the Alexandria Native Criminal Court
Mohamed Bey Said, of the Native Court of Appeal, will preside

Some local newspapers recently stated that Hassan Bey Mazloum, Assistant Private Se cretary to the Financial Adviser had been appointed as successor to Socrates Bey Spiro as Director in the Administration of Ports and Lighthouses. This is incorrect as Hassan Bey Mazloum has been appointed as Chief of the Secretariat in the Central Office of the Administration
No succe-sor has as yet been appointed to the post lately oocupied by Spiro Bey. To The Editor OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”

Sir, — In order to prevent any misapprehension on the part of your readers which may be caused by the paragraphs which appeared in the Egyptian Gazette" yesterday, it may be useful to point out that the enquiry held during the summer at the office of Ports and Lighthouses was instituted by the Head of the Administration on bis own initiative in consequence of complaints made against two of his officials by their discharged subordinates. He gummoned his Director at Port Said to assist at the enquiry and added a Custom House official, whose place was subsequently taken by a Sub-Director of the Finance Administration.
I am &c.
VERITAS. Alexandria, December 7.

div.head: CAIRO RIFLE MEETING.
div.p: The annual Army and Navy Rifle meeting will take place on the Abbassia Ranges on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the Srd, 4th, 5th and 6th of February, 1908. All communiaations on the subject should be addressed to the Hon. Secretary, Cairo Rifle Meeting, Abbassia Barracks, Cairo. The Hon. Treasurer and Hon. Secretary is Lieut. Sir
W.B. Barttelot, Bart, 3rd Bn. Coldstream | Guards

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING. SUPPRESSION OF THE DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The supression--for that is what it amounts to-of the Department of Mines had been romoured for a considerable time, so that the actual carrying out of this important thange has excited less surprise than it might otherwise have done. There still, however, remains an element of wonder at this action of the Government, for when it is considered what a large amount of both time and money has been expended in conducting the preliminary work necessary to the ultimate success of the depart ment, it seems to be a matter for regret that it should have been found necessary to suspend operations just at the time when everything had been pat on a sound working basis and the real work of the Department was about to commence.

We understand that the Director in his preliminary report to the Government affirmed that it would not be until the year 1908 that any tangible results could be expect ed, as in his opinion it would be impossible to carry out the organization of the Department in a less time. Thus it happens that now at the close of 1907, when the station at Edfou stands in perfect readiness for the carrying through of any necessary experiments, and all is ready for the start, the Government has chosen to abolisb-or at least practically abolish-the Department altogether.

It may very possibly be that in the opin. ion of the Government, the country is not yet in a sufficiently advanced position to justify further expenditure on what is, after all, a practically unknown quantity, but surely if this is the case, there must have been a deplor able lack of forethought exercised by those to whom the formation of the Department of Mines was originally due, if the Department was intended only to make the crudest investigations into the mining and geological possibilities of the country, then the expenditure at Edfou was entirely unjustifiable and should have been checked. If however the work, which has been carried on, bas been in accordance with the ideas and intentions of the Government, it is more than ever surprising that this time should have been chosen for their sudden alterations in plan.

It would be interesting to know the precise reasons which has prompted the Government to take this drastic action. We believe it to be primarily due to motives of economy, but on the other hand it is an undoubted fact that an oil field of considerable value has already been discovered, marble and sulphur have been found, both of good quality and in presumably workable quantities, and for the de velopment of the pottery industries alone it might have been imagined that a further lease of life would bave been allotted to the Department responsible for these discoveries. While it is true that as far as gold is concerned, the results have been somewhat disappointing, it is in only very few countries where gold can be said to be the staple form of mineral wealth. There is gold in Egypt. There are emeralds and rubies also. But because neither are found in extraordinary quantities is no reason why the existence of other minerals should be ignored in the great portion of the country as yet unexplored, and such discoveries as have already been made augurs hopefully for the future. We believe that there are still one or two men of the former Department to be retained to act in their original positions, and it may be that the working is therefore simply to remain in abeyance. In the meanwhile we trust that the money spent in the formation of the Edfou base, and in the accumulation of the necessary details pertaining to it will not prove to be so much money wasted.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE".

Sir, -In reference to the unfortunate in cidents that have of late occurred in regard to Limited Liability Companies registered in London, but whose sphere of operations is in Egypt and whose board of directors is only composed of subjects of foreign Powers, the only remnedy is to require the entire board to be composed of British subjects amenable to British Consular juridiction, thus avoiding the interminable delays and technical difficulties of the Mixed Tribunals. An Act of Parliament could be passed for this purpose without any difficulty, as by this time the authorities at home should be aware of the abuse by for eigners in Egypt of the businesslike facilities afforded by the English Law for the formation of companies.
Truly Yours
LEX Cairo. December 5th.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The 8.8. "Belgian Prince" is due to arrive at Alexandria from Partington about the 7 to 8th December
The S.S. "Trojan Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 6th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Tuesday next.
The 8.8. "Creole Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 6th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 22nd December
The Moss liner, "Karnak," sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due bere on | Tuesday morning the 10th inst, with passengers, mails and a general cargo.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY. MR. FLETCHER'S WORK.
div.p: At á meeting of the general committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society on the 4th inst, Mr. Frederick Fletcher, M.A. (Cantab), B. So (Lond), Principal of Agriculture, Gizeh, was elected a member of the executive committee.

Mr. Fletober was from 1901 to 1903 lecturer on agriculture at the School of Agriculture, Gizeh, and has returned to that school as successor to Dr. Mackenzie after some tour years' valuable and varied experience in India as Deputy Director of Agriculture for the Bombay Presidency Mr. Fletcher was elected foundation scholar of St. John's College, Cambridge, in natural science, and after taking the B.A. degree he proceed to the agricultural department of the university and obtained the diploma in agriculture. During his two years at the School of Agriculture at Gizeh he commenced breeding experiments with Egyp tian cotton, and gave special attention to making a complete collection of the varieties of cotton grown all over the world. Before leaving Egypt be passed the departmental examination in Arabic, and wrote a handbook on "Egyp tian Insect Pests." In India Mr. Fletcher's work included the organisation of a depart ment of practical agriculture, and the establishment of experimental farms for cotton growing in various parts of th Bombay Presidency. Mr. Fletcher continued to give attention to the collection of cottons, and a largely illustrated monograph compiled by him on this subject is now being printed by the Government of Bombay. Among other agricultural questions taken up by Mr. Fletcher may be mentioned the introduction of Egyptian cotton into the Indus valley, and an investigation of the so-called "exhaustion" of soils, on which latter subject he prepared a special paper now being printed by the Agricultural Department of the Government of ludia. Mr. Fletcher has been able to see a considerable improvement in the quality of cotton grown in the Bombay Presidency, and he was not infrequently called upon by other provinces to advise on questions connected with cotton and irrigation for Agricultural purposes. His special knowledge of the vast projects of irrigation in the unreclaimed tracts of the Punjab places him in the front rank of authorities in Egypt on so important a subject as land reclamation.

The Ministry of Education and the new Department of Agriculture and Technical Education are to be congratulated upon having segured the services of an agricultural expert and administrator with such wide and important experience, and it may be expected that the School of Agriculture and also the Khedivial Agricultural Society will largely benefit as a result of the appointment of Mr. Fletcher.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT. MONTANA V. ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon and this morning the case of Mr. Montana v. the Anglo-Egyptian Bank was heard at the British Consulate before Judge Cator of the Supreme Consular Court. Counsel for the plaintiff was Mr. Halford assisted by Mr. Moss, the counsel for the defence being Mr. A.W. Preston. Mr. Montana claims a sum of £3,000 (approximately) on the grounds of having instructed on July 3, 1907 the Anglo-Egyptian Bank to pay in London by telegram a sum of £11,016 due on July 16,1907, and that his instructions were not carried out. The amount having been deposited at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Alexandria, the Bank telegraphed the same to beir London office, but, it is alleged, neglected to insert in their telegram the fact that the snm mentioned was domiciled at the Bank of Egypt; the complainant thus claims damages on the ground of loss of credit During yesterday afternoon the witnesses heard were Mr. Ralli, Mr. E. Moss, Mr. Triandas and Mr. G. Morris. The case was adjourned at ten minutes to one this afternoon until 2 p.m.

div.head: MEN-OF-WAR AT PORT SAID.
div.p: H.H.S. "Venus" came out of the Canal on Tuesday night, and will proceed to Sardinia on Sun'ay morning.
H.MS. "Amphitrite" first class cruiser arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Colombo and leaves to-day for Chatham.
H.M.S. "Diana" will remain at Port Said a few days longer.

div.head: THE CITIES OF THE EGYPTIAN SULTANS
div.p: Residents in Egypt, who are thinking of making Christmas boxes for their friends at home, could not do better than order their booksellers to send them Professor Margolionth's new book on the cities of the Egyptian Sultans, Cairo, Jerusalem and Damasous. The illustrations in colour by Mr. Water Tyrwhitt give a most vivid and artistic representation of Oriental Cairo and the letter press is as interesting as the pictures are beautiful. It is needless to mention that all the historical details are of extreme accuracy in a work coming from such a polymath as the Landian Professor of Arabic. Professor Margoliouth, who dedicates the book to the Princess Nazli Hanem, in his preface to the work says that its compilation was "s relief from the labour of editing and translating Arabic texts. The | chance of being associated at any time in hi | life with the fine arts constituted a temp
tation which he was unable to resist." Messrs Chatto and Windus are the publishers.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL,
div.p: Our telegrams annonnce the engagement of Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria to the Princess Eleonora of Reuss. The Princess is the sister of Henry XXIV, Prince of Reuss-Köstritz. She was born at Trebschen in 1860 and is one year older than Prince Perdinand. His first wife was a Bourbon of the Parma Branch, who died in 1899 at the age of 29.
Prince Anatole Lieven and the Princess Lieven and family, the Hon. Mr. Overend, Sir Stephen Mackenzie and Lord Eustace Cecil have arrived at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan.

Other arrivals at the Cataract Hotel include Mr. and Mrs. H. Pembroke, Mr and Mrs. Parker, Mr. A. Cecil, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Bradley, Mrs. Pense, Mrs. Bewley, Miss Breithaupt, Mr. and Mrs. W. The latest arrivals at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum, include: Prince Demidoff, Mr. André Yvers, Mr. G. V. Sobolewsky, Herr Connerzienrath J. Abrens and Mrs Ahrens, Captain Dalrymple, Mr. Mauricio Mayer, Mr. and Mrs. F. A. Raikes, Mrs. Edgar Lubbeck, Mr. Charles N. Peacock Mr. Percy P. Martin, Mr. Bertran Archer, Mr. W. M. Aders.

Mr. H. T. Monson, the well-known AngloEgyptian agricultural expert is now in London. He caught typhoid fever while ont in the desert last September year and carried it to England with him last Deveinber. He has been ill ever since, but and is now slowly recovering.

The principal agent of the Khedivial Mail Line at Constantinople, Alfred Silley Bey, has been decorated by the Sultan with the order of the Lakhat, with the gold medal, for having promptly isolated two cases of cholera at Constantinople.
Mrs. Frederick Colman, accompanied by Mr. Gordon Colman, are expected at Alexandria from London this month
We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Eliza Brookfield Percival, widow of the late Job Brown Percival of Liverpool, which occurred at Fleming, Ramleh, yesterday morning at the age of 66 years.

The following passengers left Cairo yesterday for Upper Egypt by the Hamburg and Anglo-American S.S. "Puritan" :- Mr. C. G. Pfeffer, Mr. Surleau, Miss Carr, George Wissa Bey, Youssuf Sahib Bey, Rachid Bey, Aly Bey Hamad, Mr. and Mrs. Bergdirektor Klötzer, Mr. Aly Saddik, Mr and Mrs. Mantell, Aly Pasha Sabet, Mr. and Mrs. P. div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Le programme du spectacle cinématographique de demain après-midi, étant composé de vues tout à fait nouvelles, ne manquera pas d'intéresser les nombreux habitués du Casino. Une des pellicules, toute récente, représente le "Pacte infernal", grande féerie en couleur avec 16 tableaux. Le spectacle sera précédé da concert Hackmayer, qui commencera comme d'ordinaire à 4 heures. Y
